channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Supreme Court upholds law requiring age checks for porn sites
item.description: More than 20 states require age verification to protect young people from accessing lewd online content. The justices rejected arguments from the porn industry that the Texas law violates the First Amendment rights of adults by requiring them to share identifying information that could be sold, misused or hacked.

item.title: Supreme Court sides with religious parents seeking to opt out of lessons with LGBTQ storybooks
item.description: The 6-3 decision backed a group of parents seeking to withdraw their children from public school lessons featuring gay and transgender characters, a case that mixed parental rights and religious freedom.

item.title: Supreme Court upholds Affordable Care Act’s preventive-care mandate
item.description: The justices ruled against a Christian-owned business and individuals who objected to being forced to offer medications intended to prevent the spread of HIV among at-risk populations. The challengers argued that the panel that determined what care must be covered was improperly appointed.

item.title: Supreme Court limits nationwide orders blocking Trump’s birthright citizenship ban
item.description: The 6-3 ruling will impact decisions by lower-court judges to block President Donald Trump’s ban on birthright citizenship and probably other Trump administration initiatives. The president asked the justices to scale back those injunctions, which halted his policies nationwide while legal challenges to them were pending.

item.title: Supreme Court is ruling on major remaining cases, including nationwide injunctions and birthright citizenship. Follow our coverage.
item.description: The justices have left some of the most important and contentious cases until the end. They are slated to release six opinions, including decisions that will deal with injunctions regarding President Donald Trump’s ban on birthright citizenship, whether parents can opt their children out of school lessons involving LGBTQ books, and a Texas law that requires age verification to view online porn.

item.title: DOGE enters ATF with mandate to slash gun regulations as Trump administration pushes to drastically reduce number of inspectors
item.description: The U.S. DOGE Service is working with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives general counsel to cut more than 50 regulations. Gun-control advocates fear the changes will more easily allow potentially dangerous people to obtain weapons with little recourse.

item.title: Supreme Court. DOGE and guns. Young Democrats. Iran strikes. Diddy trial. Another heat wave. Fireball video. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Bill Moyers dies at 91. The acclaimed journalist won renown for bringing discussion of ideas — both timely and timeless — to TV.
item.description: He was White House press secretary under Lyndon B. Johnson and Newsday publisher before beginning a television career that would bring him more than 30 Emmy Awards, including one for lifetime achievement. He was mainly associated with PBS, and although he frequently explored societal ills, he was happier speaking with poets and philosophers than he was with pollsters or politicians.

item.title: RFK Jr. appointees vote to effectively remove a flu shot preservative, advancing a priority of anti-vaccine activists
item.description: The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices — overhauled by Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — voted Thursday to stop recommending flu shots containing the preservative thimerosal, which research has shown is safe. Most flu shots are thimerosal-free, but public health experts said the move could make shots more expensive and harder to receive. Many also expressed concern that anti-vaccine rhetoric is becoming official government guidance.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Brother’s two broken engagements have family balking at his third
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Brother’s two broken engagements have family balking at his third

item.title: Our analysis of the NBA draft’s winners and losers: Mavericks made the easy choice with Cooper Flagg, but Pelicans took risks
item.description: Dallas selected the Duke star with the No. 1 pick in the draft Wednesday night, before other teams followed more questionable paths. NBA writer Ben Golliver analyzes all of the biggest decisions.

item.title: Supreme Court paves way for states to defund Planned Parenthood, ruling Medicaid patients cannot sue for non-abortion care
item.description: The case addressed whether a provision of the federal Medicaid Act allows individuals to sue for access to their provider of choice. It was brought by a woman who wants South Carolina to resume Medicaid funding to Planned Parenthood for non-abortion health care.

item.title: In closing arguments of Sean Combs trial, prosecutors say he ‘used power, violence and fear to get what he wanted.’ Follow live.
item.description: The jury in Sean “Diddy” Combs’s sex-trafficking case has heard more than six weeks of testimony from 34 witnesses. Now, the prosecution and defense will make their final pitches to the jurors deciding Combs’s fate.

item.title: This ecosystem is in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Immigration is driving population growth in a graying America, census data shows. See how your county’s population has changed.
item.description: Children still outnumber older adults, but the gap is narrowing as baby boomers age, the data found. A historic rise in immigration, particularly among Hispanics and Asians, has counteracted some of the decline in births.

item.title: Intelligence leak. Unprecedented lawsuit. Kids’ vaccines. Zohran Mamdani. Aging population. Heat dome. Bear escape. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Dallas Mavericks select Duke forward Cooper Flagg with No. 1 pick in NBA draft
item.description: Flagg, an 18-year-old from Maine, is widely considered the best American prospect to enter the league in more than a decade. He immediately becomes the face of a Mavericks franchise that traded superstar Luka Doncic to the Los Angeles Lakers in February.

item.title: Trump administration plans to limit intelligence sharing with Congress after leaks undermined president’s claims about Iran strikes
item.description: Details of an early intelligence assessment leaked to the press this week undermined President Donald Trump’s claim that U.S. strikes “obliterated” Iranian nuclear facilities.

item.title: Dept. of Housing and Urban Development to move from D.C., displacing National Science Foundation in nearby Alexandria, Virginia
item.description: It will be the first major federal agency to relocate its headquarters outside of Washington, part of a larger plan to reorganize the federal government's real estate footprint. About 2,700 HUD workers would make the move, pushing out about 1,800 employees at the NSF, which has faced massive spending cuts under the Trump administration.

item.title: Trump DOJ sues 15 federal judges in Maryland over deportation order. Legal experts call it an unprecedented attack on judiciary.
item.description: Government lawyers say they’re aiming to preserve President Donald Trump’s constitutional authority over immigration.

item.title: Can’t do a road trip this summer? Try our tour of East Coast recipes, from Maine lobster rolls to Florida key lime pie.
item.description: Can’t do a road trip this summer? Try our tour of East Coast recipes, from Maine lobster rolls to Florida key lime pie.

item.title: RFK Jr.’s new vaccine panel to review childhood immunization schedule, a move that could change how and when kids receive shots
item.description: The newly formed vaccine advisory committee handpicked by Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. announced it would examine the cumulative effect of the childhood vaccine schedule and reevaluate hepatitis B immunization recommendations. Kennedy, who founded an anti-vaccine group, has long called for an investigation into the number of shots children receive.

item.title: Look out: The number of nuclear countries could double
item.description: What’s making some countries daydream about nukes again?

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Old friend’s new wife spills awkward secret at dinner
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Old friend’s new wife spills awkward secret at dinner

item.title: How much would you save or lose with Trump’s ‘big’ tax bill? Try our calculator to find out.
item.description: President Donald Trump and Republicans in Congress are on the cusp of passing legislation to extend tax cuts and reduce spending on safety net programs. See how the bill would affect your finances — and those of other Americans — using our tool.

item.title: Trump administration prepares to test law by delaying or withholding spending, officials say, which could shift power from Congress
item.description: The White House denies any funds have been “impounded.” But congressionally mandated projects have been put on hold or frozen across the government, potentially setting up a clash.

item.title: Special delivery in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: Iran poll. NYC primary results. Trump’s tax bill. ‘Alligator Alcatraz.’ Heat wave. Microplastics. Bezos’s wedding. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Cuomo concedes to Mamdani in New York City’s Democratic mayoral primary
item.description: “Tonight was not our night,” the former governor told supporters. He said of Mamdani: “Tonight is his night. He deserved it. He won.” Mamdani, a democratic socialist, is now poised for a major upset in the Democratic race after jumping out to a lead after the first round of ballots were tallied Tuesday. Final results in the ranked-choice voting primary are expected to come next week. The Democratic nominee is expected to begin as a favorite in the general election in a heavily blue city.

item.title: Zohran Mamdani leads Andrew M. Cuomo on 1st round of counting in New York Democratic mayoral primary
item.description: Mamdani, who would be New York’s first Muslim mayor, didn’t break the 50 percent mark in the first round of counting, the Associated Press reported. But it was still a good performance for the 33-year-old democratic socialist state assemblyman, a relative newcomer who was facing off with a former governor with copious campaign cash and prominent endorsements. Under the city’s ranked choice system, officials will now drop the candidate who finished last and continue counting votes until a candidate bests 50 percent.

item.title: We texted 1,000 Americans about Trump’s Iran strikes. Here’s what they said.
item.description: A Washington Post flash poll finds the airstrikes remain unpopular, but Republican support surged after President Donald Trump ordered the strikes.

item.title: U.S. bombs set back Iran's nuclear program by months, but did not destroy it, say people familiar with secret Pentagon assessment
item.description: President Donald Trump and top aides have claimed that U.S. airstrikes obliterated Iran's nuclear program, but people familiar with an initial report by the Defense Intelligence Agency say that core components of Tehran's enrichment program remain intact.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Friend’s sudden death brings acute sense of last moments
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Friend’s sudden death brings acute sense of last moments

item.title: When heat rises, here are 3 ways to protect your mind and body
item.description: Persistent heat can cause chronic health problems. Here's how to avoid heatstroke, manage summer depression and, when temperatures are not dangerous, enjoy nature's healing benefits.

item.title: A new label law in todayʼs On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Trump accuses Israel and Iran of violating ceasefire hours after its start
item.description: As Israel and Iran traded accusations, President Donald Trump said the two countries need to “calm down. Ridiculous.” Trump had announced the ceasefire deal on Monday as an end to what he said should be called the “12-day war.”

item.title: Shaky ceasefire. Supreme Court. New York primary. Abortion rights. Food labels. Humidity. Space images. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Israel agrees to Trump’s proposed ceasefire with Iran
item.description: Israel said it achieved its military goals in Iran and thanked President Donald Trump and the U.S. “for their participation in removing the Iranian nuclear threat.”

item.title: Trump claims Iran and Israel have agreed to a ceasefire and an imminent end to their war
item.description: In his announcement on social media, President Donald Trump congratulated both countries, saying the conflict “could have gone on for years, and destroyed the entire Middle East.” There was no immediate corroborating announcement from either the Israeli or Iranian governments.

item.title: Netanyahu decided on Iran war last year, then sought to recruit Trump
item.description: The Israeli prime minister issued a general order in the fall to prepare for a strike, current and former officials say. Israel also tried to sway the U.S. with intelligence about Iran’s nuclear plans, but American analysts did not conclude Iranian leaders had decided to build a bomb.

item.title: Supreme Court for now allows Trump to deport migrants to ‘third countries’
item.description: The six conservative justices cleared the way for the Trump administration to deport citizens of other countries to a third nation, temporarily blocking a decision by a lower court judge who said migrants must have a “meaningful opportunity” to contest their removal. The case is one of several testing the Trump administration’s aggressive efforts to ramp up deportations, in this case to conflict-ridden South Sudan.

item.title: See images of faraway galaxies and nearby asteroids from the new Vera Rubin telescope and world’s largest digital camera
item.description: The observatory, named for a pioneering American astronomer, will soon embark on a 10-year “deep and wide” survey of the entire sky in the Southern Hemisphere, promising to see more galaxies than ever seen before. The telescope features a 3,200-megapixel camera. See some of its first images here.

item.title: Explosions reported near U.S. military base in Qatar after Iran vows to retaliate for Trump’s strike on its nuclear sites
item.description: The development coincided with a warning from the U.S. Embassy in Qatar for American citizens there to shelter in place. Qatar also closed its airspace and suspended flights as a “precautionary measure” while the Middle East braces for a potential expansion of the fighting between Israel and Iran.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Friend cuts ties after being called on hurtful remark
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Friend cuts ties after being called on hurtful remark

item.title: ‘You have 12 hours to escape’: An Israeli warning to a top Iranian general reveals a covert campaign to destabilize Tehran
item.description: An audio recording of a June 13 phone call obtained by The Washington Post offers a window into the stealth campaign by Israeli intelligence to threaten and divide Iranian military and government officials.

item.title: An extreme heat warning covers the D.C. area today and tomorrow, with near-record highs expected. Here’s what to know.
item.description: Temperatures are expected to reach the upper 90s to low 100s both afternoons and perhaps on Wednesday. When high humidity is factored in, it will feel as hot as near 110, and the National Weather Service has warned of risks of heat-related illnesses.

item.title: Harvard flouted the rules. Now, it’s getting a hard lesson, Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi L. Noem writes in an op-ed.
item.description: Hosting foreign students is a privilege that comes with obligations, Noem writes.

item.title: A pay raise in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: What satellite images reveal about damage to Iran’s nuclear sites
item.description: The images provide the first glimpses of the aftermath of U.S. strikes on three sites said to be central to Iran’s nuclear program, revealing severe damage at aboveground facilities as well as the entry points left by bombs that burrowed deep underground to target some of the program’s most protected operations.

item.title: Iran’s response. Trump’s decision. Mahmoud Khalil. Minnesota suspect. Brutal heat. AI and jobs. NBA Finals. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.
